comments:
Build ID:  I20070625-1500

Steps To Reproduce:
1. Look at the ZIP I will attach of a Plug-in from existing JAR files
2. Note that in the Package Explorer commons-lang.jar does not show a package org/apache/commons/lang/enum
3. Run jar -tf commons-lang.jar and notice the package is there

More information:

I ran into this problem converting from 3.2.2 to 3.3.  Several
plug-ins that only contain 3rd party JAR files, reported errors in
MANIFEST.MF after the conversion.  These errors say:

"package 'xxx' does not exist in this plug-in"

The xxx package also does not appear when you expand the JAR file in
Package Explorer or Navigator.  These projects showed no errors in
Eclipse 3.2 (and earlier versions), and the packages did appear in the
Project Explorer.  The packages (or at least the directories) _are_ in
the JAR file.

It can be verified that the packages are there by using "jar tf
<jar-name>" or WinZip.

If you make a new "Plug-in from existing JAR archives", these packages
are not in the created MANIFEST.MF nor do they show in Project
Explorer (so there are no errors indicated).  However, they _are_
still in the JAR file.  I have tried this in a clean Eclipse 3.3 in a
clean workspace with no extra plug-ins installed.

I note that in some cases these are not really packages, but are
directories of, say, html files.  However, other such directories do
show.  Also I have at least one example of a directory (and presumably
package) with .class files.

I also note that this is reproducible but apparently random.  Most JAR
files work OK and most packages are shown in the ones that don't work.
The ones with problems have the same problem in different instances
of Eclipse (to the extent I have tested).

I will attach a ZIP of a project I made using "Plug-in from existing
JAR archives" with some of the bad JAR files.  They are all 3rd party
and not my files.

These are the problem packages in the project.

commons-lang.jar:
org.apache.commons.lang.enum

Isaw.jar:
IsawHelp.viewers.3D_view_files
but not other, similar IsawHelp.viewers.*

sgt_vz.jar:
gov.noaa.pmel.sgt.*.class-use (11 total)

Thanks,

     -Ken
Still waiting for the promised ZIP and JAR files.

I apologize.  I know that I did go through the steps of attaching it when I submitted the bug.  When I tried to do it again, I got:

The file you are trying to attach is 11546 kilobytes (KB) in size. Non-patch attachments cannot be more than 2000 KB.
We recommend that you store your attachment elsewhere on the web, and then insert the URL to it in a comment, or in the URL field for this bug.
Alternately, if your attachment is an image, you could convert it to a compressible format like JPG or PNG and try again.

So perhaps that happened the first time, and I didn't see it.

I have put it at:

ftp://ftp.aps.anl.gov/pub/evans/JAR Problem.zip

It will not stay there forever, however.

It is now:

ftp://ftp.aps.anl.gov/pub/evans/JARProblem.zip

to avoid the problem with spaces in the name.

Sorry.

I'm seeing "org.apache.commons.lang.enum" in "commons-lang.jar".

"IsawHelp.viewers.3D_view_files" is not a valid package name. However the folder "3D_view_files" appears under the package "IsawHelp.viewers".

"gov.noaa.pmel.sgt.*.class-use" are not valid package names. But each parent package contains the folder "class-use" as expected.

Maybe you are using the Package Explorer filter to filter out Non-Java Elements ?

>> Maybe you are using the Package Explorer filter to filter out Non-Java Elements

If so, I didn't do anything to make that happen.  I, in fact, don't know how to do that.  I am using the same workspace as I was before upgrading to 3.3, and I have not changed any preferences related to Project Explorer.  (The Eclipse 3.3 is a clean install, but using the old workspace.)  The non-Java elements show as white.

>> I'm seeing "org.apache.commons.lang.enum" in "commons-lang.jar".

I do not.  See attached screen dump.  It also shows what I get for gov.noaa.sgt.*.

Except for the Apache one, it is true they are not valid packages.  However, it shows some of these and not others (for me).  The same is true of the Isaw.jar, but there was not enough room in the screen dump.

I do not have this problem with my old 3.2.2 Eclipse, which is still running on my laptop.  I see all the packages, valid or not.

In addition, the 3.2.2 (or previous) wizard put all the valid and invalid packages in MANIFEST.MF.  The 3.3 version seems to not put the invalid ones, which is good.  I noticed the problem because the ones that were put in by 3.2.2 became errors when converted to 3.3.  The reason is, the same as for the project Explorer, that Eclipse doesn't see them.  (For me, anyway).  Note that Eclipse 3.3 does not mark invalid packages as errors, just the ones it thinks are missing.

As stated in the original post, I have tried this in a clean Eclipse 3.3 in a
_clean_ workspace with no extra plug-ins installed, and get the same result (missing packages as in the screen dump).

Thanks for looking at this.

Created an attachment (id=75865)
Screen dump of Project Explorer as I get it.

I now understand the problem with "org.apache.commons.lang.enum". The compliance of your project is 1.5. In 1.5 "enum" is a reserved keyword and thus "org.apache.commons.lang.enum" is not a valid package name. The problem is that we don't show "enum" as a non-Java element. We should fix that.

>  However, it shows some of these and not others (for me).
Could you please elaborate ? What exact packages doesn't it show that it should show ?

>> Could you please elaborate ? What exact packages doesn't it show that it should show ?

From the original post:

Isaw.jar:
IsawHelp.viewers.3D_view_files [is missing]
but not other, similar IsawHelp.viewers.*

They all seem to have two .jpg files.  It doesn't show IsawHelp.viewers.3D_view_files, but shows the others.

Also from the original post:

sgt_vz.jar:
gov.noaa.pmel.sgt.*.class-use (11 total) [are missing]

(These are missing in the screen dump.  The Isaw.jar ones don't show in the screen dump, but are also missing.)

Note that when they are missing in the Package Explorer, they also cannot be added to MANIFEST.MF.  (Since these above are not really packages, this is not a problem.  However it is a problem for org.apache.commons.lang.enum.)

I am on vacation, hence the slow response.  Sorry.

(In reply to comment #8)
> Isaw.jar:
> IsawHelp.viewers.3D_view_files [is missing]
For me "3D_view_files" appears as a non-Java element under package "IsawHelp.viewers".

> sgt_vz.jar:
> gov.noaa.pmel.sgt.*.class-use (11 total) [are missing]
For me "class-use" appears as a non-Java element under package "gov.noaa.pmel.sgt.awt".

> 
> (These are missing in the screen dump.  The Isaw.jar ones don't show in the
> screen dump, but are also missing.)
From the screen dump, it appears that you have not expanded "gov.noaa.pmel.sgt.awt". If you did, "class-use" would be shown as a child of "gov.noaa.pmel.sgt.awt".

> Note that when they are missing in the Package Explorer, they also cannot be
> added to MANIFEST.MF.  (Since these above are not really packages, this is not
> a problem.  However it is a problem for org.apache.commons.lang.enum.)
Right, you won't be able to able to add "org.apache.commons.lang.enum" since it is not a valid package name.

> IsawHelp.viewers.3D_view_files [is missing]
For me "3D_view_files" appears as a non-Java element under package
"IsawHelp.viewers".

It does not appear for me.  

> sgt_vz.jar:
> gov.noaa.pmel.sgt.*.class-use (11 total) [are missing]
For me "class-use" appears as a non-Java element under package
"gov.noaa.pmel.sgt.awt".

Again, it does not for me.

> (These are missing in the screen dump.  The Isaw.jar ones don't show in the
> screen dump, but are also missing.)
From the screen dump, it appears that you have not expanded
"gov.noaa.pmel.sgt.awt". If you did, "class-use" would be shown as a child of
"gov.noaa.pmel.sgt.awt".

Yes, I did not expand "gov.noaa.pmel.sgt.awt" in the screen dump.  If I had, they would not show.  However, in what I did expand, there should be "gov.noaa.pmel.sgt.class-use".  Presumably you would see this whereas it is not in the screen dump.  It would be useful to determine what is different about your situation compared to mine.  This happens for me on three machines, two with XP and one with Vista.  I am using Eclipse 3.3.0, and it happens with a new install and clean workspace.  There was no such problem with 3.2.2 or prior.

> Note that when they are missing in the Package Explorer, they also cannot be
> added to MANIFEST.MF.  (Since these above are not really packages, this is not
> a problem.  However it is a problem for org.apache.commons.lang.enum.)
Right, you won't be able to able to add "org.apache.commons.lang.enum" since it
is not a valid package name.

It is not a valid package name for 1.5 as I understand it.  If I change the compliance to 1.4, it still does not show.  Moreover, the proper behavior would be to display the package with an error (or possibly a warning for 1.4 compliance), not to just omit it.  Omiting it is user unfriendly and is of no help in fixing the problem.

Please note that these are 3rd-party JARs, not mine.  I am just wrapping them, as that is the best, if not the only feasible, way to use them in Eclipse.  I am not at liberty to change them.

Thanks,

     -Ken

Here are the steps I followed:
1. Unzip "eclipse-java-europa-win32.zip" to "d:\eclipse\java-europa"
2. Ensure that JDK "1.6.0_02" is on the "PATH" variable
3. Double-click "D:\eclipse\java-europa\eclipse\eclipse.exe"
4. Change workspace location to "D:\eclipse\java-europa\workspace"
5. After the workbench has come up, close the Welcome page
6. File > Import > General > Existing Projects into Workspace
7. Next
8. Select archive file > Browse
9. Select the file provided in comment 3
10. Finish
11. Expand "JAR Problem"
12. Expand "Referenced LIbraries"
13. Expand "commons-lang.jar"
14. Expand "org.apache.commons.lang"
Observe: "enum" appears as a non-Java element node (it is a child of "org.apache.commons.lang")
15. Expand "Isaw.jar"
16. Expand "IsawHelp.Viewers"
Observe: "3D_view_files" appears as a non-Java element node (it is a child of "IsawHelp.Viewers")

Could you please follow exactly these steps and tell me what is different ?

I observe the very same behavior with a new installation of Eclipse 3.3, using Java 1.5 compliance settings, and the following package names:

org.apache.axis.enum
com.esri.mo2.res.ico.bean.16
com.esri.mo2.res.ico.bean.32
com.esri.mo2.res.ico.bean.64

I have tried creating new packages with names ending in 'enum', '16', etc., and the New Java Package window states, for example, "Invalid package name. 'enum' is not a valid Java identifier".  This is correct behavior.

Certainly it is appropriate to restrict creation of such packages, but I need to export the 3rd party packages and Eclipse 3.3 does not permit this.  The Export-Package section of my plug-in's manifest gives the error: "Package 'org.apache.axis.enum' does not exist in this plug-in".

Related behavior:

1) On the Runtime tab of the manifest editor, the list obtained from the [Add...] button does not include the affected packages.

2) From the Package Explorer, class files in the affected packages cannot be opened into an editor.  The editor window opens showing an "Error opening the editor." message, and the following is reported to the log:

(In reply to comment #12)
Scott, please open separate bugs (1. against PDE/UI, 2. against JDT/Text) with steps to reproduce and Eclipse build ID.

Here are the steps I followed:

> 1. Unzip "eclipse-java-europa-win32.zip" to "d:\eclipse\java-europa"

I'm not sure where to get that ZIP file.  I instead got Eclipse
Classic from http://www.eclipse.org/downloads/.  That should be a
standard version and the one that I used before.  I overwrote the old
version with the current one.  As will be seen below, this is not an
essential difference.

I extracted to "c:\eclipseJarProblem\java-europa\"

> 2. Ensure that JDK "1.6.0_02" is on the "PATH" variable

c:\bin>java -version
java version "1.6.0_02"
Java(TM) SE Runtime Environment (build 1.6.0_02-b06)
Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (build 1.6.0_02-b06, mixed mode, sharing)

c:\bin>

> 3. Double-click "D:\eclipse\java-europa\eclipse\eclipse.exe"

Did "c:\eclipseJarProblem\java-europa\eclipse\eclipse.exe"

> 4. Change workspace location to "D:\eclipse\java-europa\workspace"

Changed to "c:\eclipseJarProblem\java-europa\workspace"

> 5. After the workbench has come up, close the Welcome page
> 6. File > Import > General > Existing Projects into Workspace
> 7. Next
> 8. Select archive file > Browse
> 9. Select the file provided in comment 3
> 10. Finish

Imported project from my regular workspace, more or less per
directions.  Checked "Copy projects into workspace".

> 11. Expand "JAR Problem"
> 12. Expand "Referenced LIbraries"
> 13. Expand "commons-lang.jar"
> 14. Expand "org.apache.commons.lang"
Observe: "enum" appears as a non-Java element node (it is a child of
"org.apache.commons.lang")

Yes, it appears as a folder, not package.  It also works that way in
my own version it turns out.  I had not thought to expand
org.apache.commons.lang, apparently.  All the other packages appear in
Package Explorer without having to do that.  That is, they appear as
org.apache.commons.lang.enum.  I am attaching screen dump 2 of what I
see.

> 15. Expand "Isaw.jar"
> 16. Expand "IsawHelp.Viewers"
Observe: "3D_view_files" appears as a non-Java element node (it is a child of
"IsawHelp.Viewers")

Yes.  This one also turns out to work that way in my own version.
Again, I had not thought to do that (expand IsawHelp.Viewers).  In
this case there is even more reason not to do do it.  Attached is
screen dump 3 of what I see.  Why is IsawHelp.Viewers.3D_view files
different from IsawHelp.Viewers.contour_view_files and the others.

> Could you please follow exactly these steps and tell me what is different ?

Nothing appears to be different.  We apparently see the same thing
(which is good).  It was a failure to communicate.  The files were not
where I expected them.  I apologize for not having figured this out.
In my defense, they are not where they were in Eclipse 3.2, and I am
still confused as to what it is doing.

We are left with the problem of why is IsawHelp.Viewers.3D_view files
treated differently from IsawHelp.Viewers.contour_view_files and the
others.  In my opinion treating them as empty packages (white package
symbols) is the better choice but I could argue either way.  In any
event, there should be consistency.

We are also left with the problem that setting the compliance to 1.4
still does not allow org.apache.commons.lang.enum to be seen as a
package or exported.  And there is no error indication that this is
[only] because it has an invalid name in J2SE 1.5.  It otherwise
qualifies to be shown and treated as a true package.  The former
problem just leads to confusion.  This one prevents things that should
be possible, for me as well as in the post by Scott.  And it hides the
problem rather than making it apparent with an error or warning.

Note that my regular workspace has JDK1.5.0_09 as the default JRE,
whereas this test workspace defaults to JDK1.6.0_02.  They seem to
behave the same way in regard to this problem, however.

Thanks,

     -Ken

Test workspace showing org.apache.commons.lang.enum as it gets expanded in Eclipse 3.3.

(In reply to comment #14)
> > 1. Unzip "eclipse-java-europa-win32.zip" to "d:\eclipse\java-europa"
> 
> I'm not sure where to get that ZIP file.  I instead got Eclipse
> Classic from http://www.eclipse.org/downloads/.  That should be a
> standard version and the one that I used before.
That is fine.

> I overwrote the old version with the current one. 
It is never recommended to unzip a version on top of another one. Instead, you should rename or delete the old sdk, and unzip the new one on a new directory.

> Observe: "3D_view_files" appears as a non-Java element node (it is a child of
> "IsawHelp.Viewers")
> 
> Yes.  This one also turns out to work that way in my own version.
> Again, I had not thought to do that (expand IsawHelp.Viewers).  In
> this case there is even more reason not to do do it.  Attached is
> screen dump 3 of what I see.  Why is IsawHelp.Viewers.3D_view files
> different from IsawHelp.Viewers.contour_view_files and the others.
"3D_view" is not a valid Java identifier (a Java identifier cannot start with a number), thus "IsawHelp.Viewers.3D_view" cannot be a package. "contour_view_files" is a valid Java identifier.

> Nothing appears to be different.  We apparently see the same thing
> (which is good).  It was a failure to communicate.  The files were not
> where I expected them.  I apologize for not having figured this out.
> In my defense, they are not where they were in Eclipse 3.2, and I am
> still confused as to what it is doing.
It appears that we fixed a bug in 3.3. In 3.2, the bug was that we incorrectly represented non-Java elements inside .jar files as packages, when they were correctly represented as folders if they were directories on disk.

> We are left with the problem of why is IsawHelp.Viewers.3D_view files
> treated differently from IsawHelp.Viewers.contour_view_files and the
> others.  In my opinion treating them as empty packages (white package
> symbols) is the better choice but I could argue either way.  In any
> event, there should be consistency.
Please see my answer above. I agree that there is little difference between these 2 names, but they are correctly represented as a non-Java element for "3D_view" and as a package for "contour_view_files".

> We are also left with the problem that setting the compliance to 1.4
> still does not allow org.apache.commons.lang.enum to be seen as a
> package or exported.  
I suspect that you saw a bug: when the compliance is changed from 5.0 to 1.4, the Package explorer is not updated. But if you exit/restart Eclipse, you should now see "org.apache.commons.lang.enum" as a package. I entered bug 201244 for this problem.

> And there is no error indication that this is
> [only] because it has an invalid name in J2SE 1.5.  It otherwise
> qualifies to be shown and treated as a true package.  The former
> problem just leads to confusion.  This one prevents things that should
> be possible, for me as well as in the post by Scott.  And it hides the
> problem rather than making it apparent with an error or warning.
Yes, I agree that we should better report that a folder is excluded from the list of packages because it is not a valid package name.

Jerome,

Thanks for your help.  Once one understands the rules, this issue does not appear to be a bug.  In spite of being confusing as well as different from before (perhaps some documentation would help) it is definitely an improvement over what was done in 3.2.  It is especially nice that it does not automatically export folders that are not packages any more or that have no classes (white package icon).

I again apologize for not figuring this out myself.  I was overloaded with problems from converting to 3.3 and have been on travel much of the time since.  In addition, since the problem started for me because I got errors (with little useful information) in a previously working MANIFEST.MF, I probably approached the problem from the wrong perspective.

>> I overwrote the old version with the current one. 
> It is never recommended to unzip a version on top of another one. Instead, you
> should rename or delete the old sdk, and unzip the new one on a new directory.

I agree.  I overwrote the previously downloaded ZIP file is all.  It may or may not have been the same.  However, it was a new install in a new directory.

In any event hopefully some good has come of this.

Thanks again,

     -Ken
No problem. I'm moving this bug to DOC so that we document this issue next time we update the help.

traces.message: The Class File Viewer cannot handle the given input.
